docs.lead_paragraph: Big banks have already taken losses of nearly $10 billion on loans gone bad, though they were far from the only institutions at fault.

docs.lead_paragraph: The American public's confidence in the health care system rose markedly after passage of the sprawling legislative package this year, according to a survey released on Wednesday by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

headline.main: Public Confidence in Health Care Dips

docs.abstract: The longtime survey by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation suggests that reality is settling in for Americans on the health care law.
docs.snippet: The longtime survey by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation suggests that reality is settling in for Americans on the health care law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Peter Katt, a fee-only life insurance consultant based in Mattawan, Mich., has bought $6 million worth of life insurance, as much as insurers will allow him to get based on his income and net worth.

headline.main: How a Life Insurance Consultant Set Up His Own Policies

docs.abstract: The strategies of Peter Katt, a fee-only life insurance consultant based in Mattawan, Mich., include buying $6 million worth of life insurance.

headline.main: Archbishop Weighs In on Islamic Center

docs.abstract: In Morning Buzz: New York's Archbishop weighs in on the Lower Manhattan Islamic Center; the President gives a lift to a bill for 9/11 first responders; bed bugs go to the movies; and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: 11:05 a.m. | Updated In his Political Times column published on Wednesday, Matt Bai offers one theory behind President Obama's fading popularity, which has divided and somewhat puzzled Democrats in Washington. He answered reader questions on what he calls the "legislative box" strategy and other top Washington issues this week.

headline.main: Obama's Struggles: Answers From Matt Bai, Part III

docs.abstract: The Political Times columnist is taking questions from readers this week.
docs.snippet: The Political Times columnist is taking questions from readers this week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dog bites cost American home insurers 6.4 percent more in 2009 than in the previous year, with the average claim exceeding $24,000 for the third straight year, an industry group said Wednesday.

headline.main: Insurers Feeling Pain of Dog Bites
headline.print_headline: Insurers Feeling Pain of Dog Bites

docs.snippet: Dog bites cost American home insurers 6.4 percent more in 2009 than in the previous year, with the average claim exceeding $24,000 for the third straight year, an industry group said Wednesday.
